item.title: Chapman Got Conferences. Birkeland Got a Banknote.
item.description: Norway put Kristian Birkeland on their 200 krone note in 1994. On the front: his face, the aurora borealis behind him, his terrella experiment — a miniature magnetized Earth he’d built in a vacuum chamber to demonstrate how solar electrons create auroral light. On the back: a map of the Arctic polar region, with a ring drawn around the magnetic dip pole, marking exactly where the currents he’d predicted flow into the ionosphere.

item.title: He Won the Nobel. They're Still Catching Up.
item.description:
In 1939, Hannes Alfvén submitted a paper on magnetic storms and auroras to the leading American geophysics journal. Rejected. It contradicted Sydney Chapman’s calculations, and Chapman was the established authority. Alfvén published it in a Swedish-language journal instead, where it reached approximately nobody who mattered at the time.

That paper became foundational work in space physics.

He summarized the experience like this: “I have no trouble publishing in Soviet astrophysical journals, but my work is unacceptable to the American astrophysical journals.”
